We had a very wonderful lifestyle while saving a lot of money. My wife and I ended up having a daughter and we were basically set with life. Exceptâ€¦ we constantly felt the class differences. We had our daughter going to a private school which costs a lot of money each month and we saw that she just was never going to ever see people of different socioeconomic statuses than her. This seriously feels sounds awful to type out in this way but I really did feel bad about my daughter having such a dramatically different and privileged life than that of her peersâ€¦ and we donâ€™t want to send her to public school when she gets old enough to because of school shootings and just the general roll of the dice that you get when attending public school in the US (and especially Texas). So we were set on moving somewhere that doesnâ€™t have nearly as much separation between upper middle class and lower class. There were other criteria as well, but that one was probably the most important to me. As you can probably tell, weâ€™ve gone further and further left and think that itâ€™s impossible for billionaires to exist without the exploitation of many, many people.

So we settled on Denmark. We liked what we knew of the education system. We liked the public infrastructure and biking culture. We liked how health care was done (which was also a stressor in the US, despite having good health insurance). We even like the general attitude of Danes which you mentioned. Keeping to yourself and respecting otherâ€™s privacy and not bothering them is a type of kindness that I appreciate greatly. And Iâ€™m an introvert so thatâ€™s fine as well. I like the direct communication that comes from Danes a lot of the time. But anyway, thatâ€™s why weâ€™re here. Our runner up was actually The Netherlands. It was close but there were a couple things we liked better about Denmarkâ€¦ including the remarkably high rate of employed women and the amount of maternity care (even though weâ€™re done having children ourselves).
